51.text: Glenview Project               Annual Technical Report E20/208, E20/450, E20/474, M20/311                2006

text:
This work generated a number of targets, and a program consisting of four diamond holes 
 and four RC holes was conducted in 2004. Downhole EM programs were completed on 
 two of the diamond holes. 
 In addition a small soil sampling program was conducted in an area displaying high near 
 –surface zinc values, defined by diamond drilling. Further rockchip samples were taken 
 in  2005  within  this  area.  Two  RC  holes  were  drilled  to  test  a  prospective  basemetal 
 horizon and gossanous zone along strike from thesurface zinc anomaly. 
 Two  additional  RC  holes  were  drilled  to  test  anomalous  basemetal  values  in  aircore 
 drilling north of the range at the Sand King prospect. 
 A review of the uranium potential of the Weld Range was also completed by consultants 
 A joint venture was formed with Midwestern Corporation to expediate the evaluation of 
 iron  ore  lenses  within  the  Hampton  project.  Rockchip  samples  of  the  known  iron  rich 
 lenses returned values upto 65% iron. Drill testing of these lenses and other targets will 
 commence in 2006.  
 Exploration activities relating to E20/208, E20/450 E20/474 and M20/311 are covered by 
 Glenview Project               Annual Technical Report E20/208, E20/450, E20/474, M20/311                2006

59.text: phase intrusion.  Further west, in the vicinity of the Mindoolah mine workings, a large quartz

60.text: monzanite is exposed in small open cuts.  Detailed contact relations are not clear from exposures

61.text: and drilling data but the southern contact of the intrusive complex appears to be subparallel to

62.text: the supracrustal units suggesting intrusion as a series of sills into the volcanic sequence.

text:
phase intrusion.  Further west, in the vicinity of the Mindoolah mine workings, a large quartz 
 monzanite is exposed in small open cuts.  Detailed contact relations are not clear from exposures 
 and drilling data but the southern contact of the intrusive complex appears to be subparallel to 
 the supracrustal units suggesting intrusion as a series of sills into the volcanic sequence.

35.text: The Glenview project covers most of a volcanic sequence that is situated north of the Weld

36.text: Range banded iron formation.  This sequence, referred to in this report as the Weld Range

37.text: volcanic sequence, is part of the larger Weld Range greenstone belt of the Murchison Province.

38.text: Watkins and Hickman (1990) defined the Murchison Supergroup as the supracrustal sequence in

39.text: the Murchison Province comprised of two groups, the Luke Creek Group and the Mount Farmer

text:
The Glenview project covers most of a volcanic sequence that is situated north of the Weld 
 Range banded iron formation.  This sequence, referred to in this report as the Weld Range 
 volcanic sequence, is part of the larger Weld Range greenstone belt of the Murchison Province.  
 Watkins and Hickman (1990) defined the Murchison Supergroup as the supracrustal sequence in 
 the Murchison Province comprised of two groups, the Luke Creek Group and the Mount Farmer

Glenview Project               Annual Technical Report E20/208, E20/450, E20/474, M20/311                2006

63.text: Massive fine-grained mafic volcanic rocks form the base of the supracrustal sequences on the

64.text: east side of the map area and intermediate volcanics and volcanics and volcaniclastics occur at

65.text: the base of the sequence on the western side of the map area.  Up-sequence transgression by the

66.text: intrusive complex probably causes the lack of mafic rocks on the western side of the map area.

text:
Massive fine-grained mafic volcanic rocks form the base of the supracrustal sequences on the 
 east side of the map area and intermediate volcanics and volcanics and volcaniclastics occur at 
 the base of the sequence on the western side of the map area.  Up-sequence transgression by the 
 intrusive complex probably causes the lack of mafic rocks on the western side of the map area.

Dominantly dacitic
 volcanics and
 volcaniclastics thickening
 eastward

8.text: south and has a southerly younging direction.  In general, there is a transition from mafic units at

9.text: the base to felsic units towards the top of the sequence.  Interfingering along strike makes

10.text: detailed correlation difficult.  The sequence is bounded to the north by an intermediate to felsic

11.text: intrusive complex that may be, in part, coeval with the volcanic rocks.  The Weld Range BIF

12.text: discordantly overlies the volcanic rocks.  There is evidence in drill holes for a fault contact

13.text: between the BIF and underlying volcanic sequence (Johnston, 2002).

20.text: 20 rock chip and gossan samples were taken along prospective basemetal horizons and in the

21.text: vacinity  of  hole  GD11  which  contained  elevated  zinc  values  in  the  precollar.  Sample  521

22.text: returned a zinc value of 0.79% with elevated lead values. This area requires further drill testing.

text:
south and has a southerly younging direction.  In general, there is a transition from mafic units at 
 the base to felsic units towards the top of the sequence.  Interfingering along strike makes 
 detailed correlation difficult.  The sequence is bounded to the north by an intermediate to felsic 
 intrusive complex that may be, in part, coeval with the volcanic rocks.  The Weld Range BIF 
 discordantly overlies the volcanic rocks.  There is evidence in drill holes for a fault contact 
 between the BIF and underlying volcanic sequence (Johnston, 2002). 
 WORK DONE DURING REPORTING PERIOD 
 Rock Chip Sampling  
 20 rock chip and gossan samples were taken along prospective basemetal horizons and in the 
 vacinity  of  hole  GD11  which  contained  elevated  zinc  values  in  the  precollar.  Sample  521 
 returned a zinc value of 0.79% with elevated lead values. This area requires further drill testing. 
 Appendix 1 contains a sample ledger of rockchips taken.  
 RC Drilling and Re-sampling 
 Four RC holes for 621 metres were drilled in two programs during the year.  
 WRRC1 and 2 were drilled to test a brecciated gossan horizon. No anomalous intercepts were

 GRC06 and 7 targeted elevated copper and lead values identified by aircore drilling. This target 
 had been drilled by a 350 metre diamond hole, GD3 but this failed to locate the source of the 
 anomalism. The two RC holes (GRC6 and 7)were drilled with an azimuth 180 degress to hole 
 GD3 to test the hypothesis of a northerly dipping target. The holes failed to intersect any cherts 
 or  mudstones  or  gossanous  rich  zones  that  could  be  the  source  of  the  elevated  copper  lead 
 values. The enrichment could be due to hydromorphic concentration in the regolith sourced from 
 an  elevated  bedrock  source  possibly  due  to  hydrothermal  activity  along  an  oblique  strike-slip

39.text: Midwest plans to commence RC drill testing of the lenses in 2006. Native title issues have

40.text: delayed the commencement of this program.

45.text: Southern  Geoscience  Consultants  compiled  the  radiometric  data  from  a  variety  of

46.text: surveys  in  order  to  review  the  uranium  potential  of  the  area  (Figure 5).  A  number of

47.text: elevated signatures were identified, the most obvious being drainage related anomalies

48.text: with the south-west corner displaying the most obvious example. A number of discrete

49.text: channel highs were also identified with a good example at 7,020,000N 570,000E. These

50.text: anoamlies require further investigation and ground inspection.

53.text: Glenview Project               Annual Technical Report E20/208, E20/450, E20/474, M20/311                2006

text:
Midwest plans to commence RC drill testing of the lenses in 2006. Native title issues have 
 delayed the commencement of this program. 
 Southern  Geoscience  Consultants  compiled  the  radiometric  data  from  a  variety  of 
 surveys  in  order  to  review  the  uranium  potential  of  the  area  (Figure 5).  A  number of 
 elevated signatures were identified, the most obvious being drainage related anomalies 
 with the south-west corner displaying the most obvious example. A number of discrete 
 channel highs were also identified with a good example at 7,020,000N 570,000E. These 
 anoamlies require further investigation and ground inspection. 
 Glenview Project               Annual Technical Report E20/208, E20/450, E20/474, M20/311                2006

31.text: on Hampton's tenements and has outlined nine target lenses to date. The lenses show good

32.text: surface expression of hematite and goethite iron mineralization. Surface sampling has returned

33.text: iron ore values generally between 60% and 65% from each of the lenses and deleterious minerals

34.text: appear to be within acceptable levels.

on Hampton's tenements and has outlined nine target lenses to date. The lenses show good 
 surface expression of hematite and goethite iron mineralization. Surface sampling has returned 
 iron ore values generally between 60% and 65% from each of the lenses and deleterious minerals 
 appear to be within acceptable levels.

12.text: During the reporting period, Hampton entered into two agreements with Midwest Corporation

13.text: Limited whereby the companies will cooperate in the exploration and potential development of

14.text: their adjacent tenement holdings situated in the Weld Range. The agreements give Hampton the

15.text: opportunity to explore for and own any non ferrous minerals occurring within the Midwest

16.text: tenement holdings while Midwest will have the right to explore for and gain majority ownership

17.text: of any iron ore resources that may occur on the Hampton tenement holdings. On the Hampton

18.text: tenements, Midwest must undertake a minimum of 2,500 metres of drilling within 12 months

19.text: and then may complete a Pre-Feasibility Study (PFS) within a further 4 years in order to earn a

20.text: 60% interest in the iron ore rights. Upon the completion of the PFS and dependant on the

21.text: planned project configuration, Hampton will have a number of options including contributing its

22.text: pro rata share of project development costs, offering its interest for sale or converting to a 2%

24.text: On the Midwest tenements, Hampton has no interest in the iron ore rights but has the right to

25.text: explore for and seek the excision of any base metal, gold or platinum group resources

26.text: provided that they do not interfere with any planned iron ore operations of Midwest. Midwest

27.text: will be entitled to a 1.5% net smelter return royalty on any non ferrous resource that is

text:
During the reporting period, Hampton entered into two agreements with Midwest Corporation 
 Limited whereby the companies will cooperate in the exploration and potential development of 
 their adjacent tenement holdings situated in the Weld Range. The agreements give Hampton the 
 opportunity to explore for and own any non ferrous minerals occurring within the Midwest 
 tenement holdings while Midwest will have the right to explore for and gain majority ownership 
 of any iron ore resources that may occur on the Hampton tenement holdings. On the Hampton 
 tenements, Midwest must undertake a minimum of 2,500 metres of drilling within 12 months 
 and then may complete a Pre-Feasibility Study (PFS) within a further 4 years in order to earn a 
 60% interest in the iron ore rights. Upon the completion of the PFS and dependant on the 
 planned project configuration, Hampton will have a number of options including contributing its 
 pro rata share of project development costs, offering its interest for sale or converting to a 2% 
 On the Midwest tenements, Hampton has no interest in the iron ore rights but has the right to 
 explore for and seek the excision of any base metal, gold or platinum group resources 
 provided that they do not interfere with any planned iron ore operations of Midwest. Midwest 
 will be entitled to a 1.5% net smelter return royalty on any non ferrous resource that is

14.text: RC drilling of the iron ore lenses by Midwestern is expected to commence during 2006.

15.text: Rock chip sampling during the year confirmed the high tenor of iron within these lenses.

51.text: Glenview Project               Annual Technical Report E20/208, E20/450, E20/474, M20/311                2006

text:
RC drilling of the iron ore lenses by Midwestern is expected to commence during 2006. 
 Rock chip sampling during the year confirmed the high tenor of iron within these lenses.

9.text: proximity  to  economic  Zn  mineralisation.  Rock  chip  sampling  in  this  area  confirmed

10.text: elevated  zinc,  lead  and  silver  values  at  surface.  A  more  extensive  surface  sampling

11.text: program is required to constrain this anomalism followed by deeper drill testing to the
